title: Large-Scale Digital Citizenship Microlearning Based on Social Media Ethics Scenarios

context.prior_knowledge: Basic social media usage experience, foundational concepts of professional ethics, understanding basic rights in civil society, and awareness of rights protection in digital environments
context.additional_context: Mobile-optimized content for working learners, featuring scenario-based learning designs reflecting real-life cases encountered in daily life. Aims to cultivate social responsibility and digital citizenship, exploring civic engagement and institutional improvement strategies through community-linked cases. Requires holistic thinking considering political/economic/cultural contexts.

learning_goals: Learners can identify five types of ethical dilemmas (personal information leakage, fake news dissemination, cyberbullying, digital divide, AI bias) that may occur on social media from a citizenship perspective and analyze them in terms of social impact and rights protection.

Within one week, learners will apply a five-step ethical decision-making framework (problem definition → stakeholder analysis → alternative evaluation → decision → evaluation) to three real-world scenario cases (workplace conflict, environmental issues, AI ethics dilemmas), write a one-page analysis report, and achieve an average score of 4 or higher on a 5-point peer evaluation scale. The report must include strategies for respecting cultural diversity and complying with legal requirements.

Learners will propose three or more legal/ethical requirements (digital rights protection, cultural diversity respect, data transparency, citizen participation assurance) to consider when establishing a social media policy within an organization and suggest citizen engagement plans, including community linkage strategies.
difficulty: Moderate - Standard complexity with some constraints
